As a pediatrician with a special focus on concussions, I read this post with great interest.

There is a building trove of data suggesting that recurrent head traumas increase the risk of early onset dementia (chronic traumatic encephalopathy). To me, the scariest part of this data is that some of these head injuries are not severe enough to cause a concussion. The very act of repetitively hitting one's head (even at sub-concussive levels) may have lasting health consequences!

While the risk of head injury is not limited to football (see men's ice hockey), the fact remains that head impacts are integral to tackle football as we now know it. The average high school lineman has ~700 head impacts during a season - this cannot be healthy.

Until there is more data available (and the experts who are studying CTE expect to have some significant guidelines in the coming years), I think it is inadvisable to allow young children to play tackle football.

The human brain is not fully developed until we are in our 20's. Until we know that a younger brain is not more vulnerable than a mature brain, it is our duty as parents to protect our children. Once children are in high school, they have a better ability to understand risk and should have more of a voice in this decision.

While I agree with the concept that we cannot raise kids in bubbles and that life is full of risks, some risks are not worth the benefit.

My vote is for no tackle football prior to high school.

Hey CRC (and others) the rise in tuition arises from a number of factors. The key drivers, however, are competition for students and money and a reduction in state support. Canada, where I live, has lower tuition because it has few private universities, and NO private university that is as good as the public ones. Canada provides more aid to its universities and there is less competition between schools. To put it succinctly, if you want lower tuition you'd best be an anti-capitalist. It is the rush of lots of people looking for universities to make them rich that has resulted in high tuitions. If everyone was majoring in philosophy university would be cheap.

True, but we've got about 3 decades before we hit the theoretical limits estimated by Richard Feynman in 1985 (in an essay in "The Pleasure of Finding Things Out"), and those limits were predicated on a transistor composed of three atoms.  If we can figure out a way to use atomic particles differently we may be able to exceed those limits.  But you are correct that a big shift in how we design computers will need to happen in our lifetimes. because of these theoretical limits.

"Such closeness is possible because the cluster of atoms is antiferromagnetic — a rare quality in which each atom in the array has an opposed magnetic orientation. (In common ferromagnetic materials like iron, nickel and cobalt, the atoms are magnetically aligned.)"

The reason the iron atoms are aligned antiferromagnetically is that for such a small array, the lowest energy state is to have the spins aligned in opposed orientation (anti-ferromagnetic) rather than in aligned orientation (ferromagnetic). This is the same reason that small enough samples of magnetic material cannot support domain walls, and remain single domain. Simple physics.

Neat result that will likely take more than a decade to be demonstrated in a commercial product.

The US Constitution was designed both to strengthen the federal government by giving it more powers than it had under the Articles of Confederation, and to protect liberty from that strengthened government by creating checks and balances permitting every branch to obstruct every other. The idea was that such a system would force govt officials to cooperate to do what was in the public interest, while removing the incentive to act in partial interests. This system requires comity and mutual respect among the different branches to get anything done. When that comity and respect breaks down, we get what we see today--a stalemate in which nothing can get done unless one branch or another claims a constitutional power to circumvent the obstruction. That is what President Obama is doing. In the process he is claiming a power that he would not claim if the system were working. Just as Senate Republicans are claiming that they can frustrate all appointments by a phony non-recess.
The American people are going to have to break this impasse by finally giving power to one party or the other, even if they don't like the party they give it to very much. Either that or have 1) continued stalemate, or 2) ever more aggressive claims to powers that otherwise would not be made. Both are too dangerous to allow to continue.
